block.p: RECORD GLOBAL TEMPERATURES The earth's average surface temperature climbed to a record high last year, bolstering scientists' sense that the burning of fossil fuels is warming the climate. A1
BOSNIAN SERB LEADER IS ISOLATED The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, is increasingly reviled and isolated among the one million Serbs he rules. A1
NATO PRESSES SERBS FOR RELEASE NATO officers visited Ilidza, a Serb-held suburb of Sarajevo, to press officials to release up to 18 Bosnian citizens being detained. A9
PALESTINIANS OPEN CAMPAIGN A Palestinian election commission in the West Bank declared the campaign open to elect the first legislature and president the Palestinians have ever had. A1
ARAFAT CRITIC IS DETAINED An outspoken Palestinian critic of human rights violations by the Palestinian Authority was detained for 24 hours and then released. A6

TWIST IN MEXICO ASSASSINATION A federal agent implicated in the assassination of the governing party's presidential candidate appeared in Mexico City and denied that he had been anywhere near the scene of the shooting. A3
DIPLOMACY ON A SHOESTRING Secretary of State Christopher grappled with his latest foreign policy nightmare: trying to conduct diplomacy on behalf of a Government that has run out of money. A6
FIGHTING FLARES IN LIBERIA Dozens of people have been killed in six days of fighting in northwestern Liberia, the worst since a cease-fire began in August. A12

MORE BUDGET TUG-OF-WAR As the budget back-and-forth continued, Republicans in the House rejected a Senate proposal to reopen the closed Federal Government briefly, and President Clinton moved to exploit the split. A1

VETOES HOLD UP House Republicans failed to override President Clinton's veto of the $256 billion military authorizations act and the $27.3 billion budget for the Commerce, State and Justice Departments. B9
THE STOP-EATING SIGNAL Scientists have found a protein that immediately tells the brain that the body should stop eating, a finding that may help in the treatment of obesity. A1
JUDGES JUMP PARTIES Underscoring the political realignment in the South, 10 judges in Birmingham, Ala., switched to the Republican Party. A14
SPECULATING ON BOMBER'S TARGET A bomb that injured an Episcopal priest in Alabama this week may have been intended for a retired Federal agent who lives nearby, investigators said. A14
STATUE PLAN COLLAPSES Plans to place a statue of the tennis star Arthur Ashe in Richmond have fallen apart. A14
MADONNA TESTIFIES The pop star Madonna testified in court against a man accused of stalking her, after a judge rejected her argument that she should not have to be in the same room with the man. A18
PATIENT TO HEAD HOME The man who received a risky experimental bone marrow transplant from a baboon three weeks ago is expected to be discharged from a hospital in San Francisco. B10
